ygData.subject: Re: How would novelty search best be applied to a virtual creature controller
ygData.msgSnippet: Peter, there is no indication that the maze solvers produced by novelty search are any less smart than those produced by fitness-based search.  As we mention

Subject: Re: How would novelty search best be applied to a virtual creature controller
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=LOfMUA7jwQSSi3Sj3SGueBI1xNZXwEjvA-gi-pxnNKSUYxvSInbm
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Peter, there is no indication that the maze solvers produced by
novelty sea=
rch are any less "smart" than those produced by
fitness-based search.  As w=
e mention in the paper briefly under
"Typical Solution," solutions from bot=
h methods just go straight to
the goal.  In other words, they do not take m=
eandering paths; they
take the most rational path and appear goal-oriented.=
  So there is no
discernible quality difference.

However, it's an interest=
ing issue because it gets to the question of
what it means to be smart vs. =
lucky.  In general, if an animal has a
behavior that gets the job done cons=
istently, one could say the animal
just "happens" to do the right thing, or=
 one could say the animal is
"smart."  In fact, I think these are one and t=
he same and the
distinction does not really add insight into the inner work=
ings
of the animal's mind.  

One of the reasons we get stuck on the issue =
of whether something is
"really" smart is because of the allure of the adap=
tive hypothesis in
evolutionary theory:  We try to explain everything we se=
e in nature in
terms of some kind of adaptation, and as soon as you assume =
that what
you are seeing is the result of an adaptation, you are susceptibl=
e to
the idea that it must be "good" in some way (which equates to "smart"
=
when decision-making is at issue).  Yet what novelty search shows is
that a=
 non-adaptive process can in many cases produce equivalent
behaviors, which=
 really turns the adaptive hypothesis upside-down, and
makes the interpreta=
tion of the "value" of a behavior more confusing.
Yet at the end of the day=
, if it works it works, regardless of why it
became the way it did.

Anyway=
, so on the question of time series, I would not be concerned
with this iss=
ue of whether it is really smart.  However, another
consideration is whethe=
r there is sufficient domain constraint to make
this search something other=
 than exhaustive enumeration.  Novelty
search relies on the properties of t=
he domain (i.e. the environment)
to create a useful landscape for the searc=
h.  Something without any
environmental constraint may not make a good sear=
ch space.  So for
example searching through all possible pictures hoping to=
 find Mona
Lisa one day may not be a good idea because just about anything =
you do
genetically produces something "novel."  In other words, there is no=

"collapse" of multiple genetic points into fewer novelty points (or
more a=
ccurately, there may not be cases of novelty points clustered
closer togeth=
er in behavior space than the corresponding genomes in
genome space).

Stil=
l, I am not sure about time series, because the distribution of
input precu=
rsor series may be thought of as a kind of constraint,
since there are some=
 precursor series you would never see.  So it may
actually work...I'm not s=
ure, but it's an interesting possibility.

ken

> Hi Ken,

u mentioned that Tyler used no inputs but just internal 
> pattern generati=
on, it reminded me about a question I wanted to ask 
> you a few days ago. =

> 
> In novelty search, it searches for new behaviors, right. But are 
> t=
hey "smart" in a sense.. For example, does the robot in the 2D maze 
> expe=
riment succeed just because of luck? It is possible that a 
> behavior that=
 appears a solution to be discovered, but the robot acts 
> like a beheaded=
 fly and reaches the solution by accident? How much 
> this depends upon th=
e environment and the inputs provided? Is it the 
> same with fitness-based=
 search? I am asking this because I am about 
> to introduce novelty search=
 to time series forecasting which is very 
> complex domain in terms of cha=
racterizing behavior. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kennet=
h Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Peter C's message brings up another i=
ssue that might be useful to
> > Peter B:  For ambulation, it might be more=
 effective to use leaky
> > integrator neurons than the usual feedforward n=
eurons that are used 
> in
> > most ANN models.  The leaky integrators are =
better for precise 
> timing.
> >  However, they may not be necessary if jo=
int angles are being 
> provided
> > as input.  But when joint angles are n=
ot provided, I do not think I
> > have ever seen a regular recurrent ANN (i=
.e. non-leaky or not some
> > other special type of neuron) be able to make=
 something walk.  In
> > fact, the "flailing" motions are often reduced sig=
nificantly by 
> leaky
> > integrator neurons.  Tyler Streeter saw this whe=
n he worked on his
> > biped with NEAT, which actually stopped flailing aft=
er switching to
> > leaky integrators.  However, in his project the network=
 had no 
> inputs
> > and worked entirely through internal pattern generati=
on.
> > 
> > ken

> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > Hi =
Peter, that's a good question and of course learning to 
> > > control a 
>=
 > > > > virtual creature with novelty search is a complicated issue 
> (an=
d 
> > > an 
> > > > > appealing idea as well). 
> > > > > 
> > > > > First=
, you have to deal with all the representational and 
> > > physical 
> > >=
 > > issues outside of novelty search, like how many inputs, how 
> many 
>=
 > > > > outputs, and whether the body itself is not physically flawed 
> i=
n 
> > > > > some way (which is possible).  As you are experiencing, the 
>=
 > > > > inputs/outputs issue can be prohibitive even with feature 
> > > >=
 > selection.  It is also possible that HyperNEAT could be 
> useful 
> > >=
 > > because it does not care about the # inputs or outputs (and 
> can 
> =
> > > > potentially exploit geometric regularities), but configuring 
> the=
 
> > > > > substrate then becomes the challenge.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Assu=
ming all of that stuff is set up well with whatever 
> system, 
> > > then =

> > > > > novelty search is a potentially winning approach.  Yet as you 
>=
 > > point 
> > > > > out there are some big questions there as well.  In f=
act, we 
> are 
> > > > > currently trying to provide the best answers to t=
hese 
> questions 
> > > in 
> > > > > ongoing research, but some general p=
rinciples might help for 
> now: 
> > > > > 
> > > > > First, the archive i=
n novelty search does not not need to 
> contain 
> > > > > every point eve=
r visited.  Therefore, it tends to grow much 
> > > slower 
> > > > > than =
the #of evaluations.  However, if it is indeed getting 
> too 
> > > big  
=
> > > > > then it is not unreasonable to collapse some of the archive 
> > =
> points, 
> > > > > although there is no standard method yet for how that =
should 
> be 
> > > > > done.  But we have reason to believe there will be =
effective 
> and 
> > > > > simple ways to do that.
> > > > > 
> > > > > Se=
cond, the issue of one individual looking different just 
> > > because 
> =
> > > > of a phase difference in effectivley the same behavior is 
> > > > =
> complicated.  For certain phase disaparities, the two 
> individuals 
> >=
 > > > won't look all that different, but it is true that at some 
> > > > =
> disparity, they may look very different.  Yet it is not clear 
> > > > > =
whether that fact is actually problematic to the novelty 
> search 
> > > o=
r 
> > > > > not, because it would simply reward both types of behavior.  
=
> It 
> > > is 
> > > > > possible that the phase difference is a result of=
 some useful 
> > > > > genotypic change, which could make it a stepping st=
one to 
> > > something 
> > > > > better.  Or, it is possible that it is s=
uperfluous 
> information 
> > > and 
> > > > > simply takes some extra tim=
e exploring the area around the 
> phase-
> > > > > shifted individual.  So=
 it is hard to say a priori whether it 
> is 
> > > a 
> > > > > major conc=
ern.  We will have better answers to such questions 
> as 
> > > the 
> > >=
 > > technique is further explored.
> > > > > 
> > > > > However, I agree t=
hat it would be nice to be able to say the 
> two 
> > > > > phase-shifted =
individuals are largely the same if that is 
> indeed 
> > > > > what you w=
ant to say.  And for that, you would need a pattern-
> > > > > matching met=
ric to compute behavioral distance, i.e. 
> something 
> > > more 
> > > > =
> sophisiticated than simple Cartesian distance.  There are 
> > > certainl=
y 
> > > > > such metrics available.  However, it's important to recognize =

> > > that 
> > > > > it is not evident at this point that ignoring the ph=
ase shift 
> is 
> > > > > actually better than taking it into consideratio=
n, because 
> taking 
> > > it 
> > > > > into consideration just means add=
ing more information to the 
> > > novelty 
> > > > > landscape.
> > > > > =

> > > > > So overall I think novelty search is a very promising 
> directi=
on 
> > > to 
> > > > > go for such problems, but it is still in the realm =
of 
> research 
> > > (i.e. 
> > > > > there is no existing precedent), so =
it will involve 
> considerable 
> > > > > trial and error to get it right =
until all these issues are 
> > > fleshed 
> > > > > out more clearly.  Ult=
imately, though, if our hypothesis 
> about 
> > > > > novelty vs. fitness =
is correct, novelty search may turn out 
> to be 
> > > > > the *only* way =
to get certain highly complex types of 
> behavior to 
> > > > > evolve in =
some domains, which is a sobering thought.  But if 
> it 
> > > is 
> > > >=
 > true, then there is not much to do other than try it.
> > > > > 
> > > >=
 > ken
